awd_titl_txt: Engaging Indigenous Youth in Sustainability Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The 2022 UArctic Assembly in Portland, Maine, offers the opportunity for Indigenous youth from New England and the Arctic to learn about sustainability science and build networks for future collaboration. This conference award supports participation of youth in activities focused on best practices for research partnerships, and sustainable development and climate adaptation strategies in Indigenous communities. Participants will have the opportunity to engage with UArctic leadership, Congressional representatives, and diplomats from Arctic nations.

Organized by the Wabanaki Youth in Science Program, the youth gathering engages Indigenous youth in learning, leadership, and collaborative activities related to sustainability science and the development of global partnerships. Participants will develop plans for a future youth sustainability conference and work on communication strategies to promote engagement. They will return to their home communities with international collaborative experience, a foundation in the principles of sustainability, and an expanded network of future Indigenous leaders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

NSF Polar Programs Social Science Workshop: Engaging Indigenous Youth in Sustainability Science

Submitted by:

 Holly Parker, PhD (PI)

Sally McCormack Tutt PT, DPT, MPH, EdD (co-PI)

Holly Parker, PI, received the NSF grant in March 2022 with the goal of hosting a gathering of New England and Arctic Indigenous youth to create a space in which these youth leaders could share their experiences in and with sustainability science and create a culturally appropriate format in which to build capacity for a larger gathering. The work accomplished due to this grant took place from March 2022 through March 2024. It is of note that in August 2022, Sally McCormack Tutt, Clinical Professor at the University of New England (UNE), joined the grant work as a co-PI when Holly Parker accepted a post at Bowdoin College, leaving UNE where the grant resides. The main outcomes of this grant were as follows:

Eleven Indigenous youth from four different countries (U.S., Canada, Greenland and Finland) gathered at the University of New England’s Biddeford campus in June of 2022 to build the trust and relationships needed to develop a framework for a future gathering of New England and Arctic Indigenous youth. The report submitted by Wabanaki Youth in Science (Appendix A), the organization that helped facilitate the gathering, details the content and structure of this work. During this time, the youth attended the UArctic Assembly meeting that was hosted at UNE. During this meeting, they conducting a talking circle which positively challenged the ways in which the institution physically structures its meetings, but also the colonial ideas that underlie those structures.

A documentary was created that tells the story of the experience and impact it had on the Indigenous youth. 

Four of the Indigenous youth (3 from Maine and 1 from Greenland) traveled to Iceland and attended the Arctic Circle Assembly in October 2022. They led a presentation that included dissemination of the documentary and facilitated a talking circle to allow participants to reflect on the documentary.

After the June 2022 gathering, the Indigenous youth continued to meet on a regular basis to plan a second Indigenous youth gathering that they would host in Maine. This gathering has not yet occurred as the youth encountered challenges with organizing such a large event.

Plans for continued dissemination of the documentary were implemented at two locations.  In April of 2023, the documentary was shared at the University of New England and again at Bowdoin college. The event was organized by the PI and Co-PI and facilitated by two of the Indigenous youth. The events consisted of a viewing of the documentary and then a talking circle to provide the opportunity for reflection and questions.
